Those were like my two favorite things, but whatever! This soundtrack is awesome and made it up to me.

snippet.textDisplay: @OrangeSteelStudios I find MM9 easier, and much more fun to play than MM1. MM1 only pissed me off so much, especially with those cyclops robot hopping around that take like 3/4 of your health with a single hit. I'm really not that big of a fan of MM1, but still acknowledge it because it was Mega Man's first appearance in the video game history.
snippet.textOriginal: @OrangeSteelStudios I find MM9 easier, and much more fun to play than MM1. snippet.textDisplay: What are you talking about?  This is a song that came from Mega Man 9, a game that was designed to replicate an NES game.  The song is one that CAN be played on an NES.  And I'm not sure what you're trying to get at with the whole "emulators in max quality".  My point is, the lower the quality, the less it sounds like the original song.
snippet.textOriginal: What are you talking about?  This is a song that came from Mega Man 9, a game that was designed to replicate an NES game.  The song is one that CAN be played on an NES.  And I'm not sure what you're trying to get at with the whole "emulators in max quality".  My point is, the lower the quality, the less it sounds like the original song.

snippet.textDisplay: That's not how it works though.  When you downgrade sound audio, it just makes it sound less like how it was originally uploaded.  Downgrading the sound quality of an mp3 file for an NES song doesn't make it sound more like an NES song, it just makes the song itself sound crappier.  You want to keep it as high-quality as possible to preserve the song as best as possible.
snippet.textOriginal: That's not how it works though.  When you downgrade sound audio, it just makes it sound less like how it was originally uploaded.  Downgrading the sound quality of an mp3 file for an NES song doesn't make it sound more like an NES song, it just makes the song itself sound crappier.  You want to keep it as high-quality as possible to preserve the song as best as possible.

We're the ro-bots,
Doctor Wily's ro-bots,
And we do a WHOLE lot,
For his master plan!"
snippet.textOriginal:
"We're the ro-bots,
Doctor Wily's ro-bots,
And we all are so not,
fond of Megaman!

We're the ro-bots,
Doctor Wily's ro-bots,
And we do a WHOLE lot,
For his master plan!"

snippet.textDisplay: @EinherjarLeo Yeah, but have you seen the cover art for the Disc release of Super Meat Boy? I'd definitely argue that that one's more epic.
snippet.textOriginal: @EinherjarLeo Yeah, but have you seen the cover art for the Disc release of Super Meat Boy? I'd definitely argue that that one's more epic.

snippet.textDisplay: @mainland09 The "Man" suffix included in nearly every Robot Master's name is just part of the long-running naming scheme. The name "Mega Boy" sounds fairly bad to begin with, so plastering it into the middle of every other "Man" character would make it seem out of place.
snippet.textOriginal: @mainland09 The "Man" suffix included in nearly every Robot Master's name is just part of the long-running naming scheme. The name "Mega Boy" sounds fairly bad to begin with, so plastering it into the middle of every other "Man" character would make it seem out of place.

snippet.textDisplay: @Duorsa The graphical engine is 8 bits, which means it's, yes, 1 byte. Now, the size of the game itself isn't only a byte of information. Pick the first Megaman game, for example, it said in the box that it had one Megabit of memory, which equals to 125 KB as aforementioned. But don't worry, that's a common mistake, even Stuttering Craig mistook both.
snippet.textOriginal: @Duorsa The graphical engine is 8 bits, which means it's, yes, 1 byte. Now, the size of the game itself isn't only a byte of information. Pick the first Megaman game, for example, it said in the box that it had one Megabit of memory, which equals to 125 KB as aforementioned. But don't worry, that's a common mistake, even Stuttering Craig mistook both.

snippet.textDisplay: @kffeine so nes games are a byte?
snippet.textOriginal: @kffeine so nes games are a byte?

snippet.textDisplay: To tell the truth, I started madly laughing when I first saw this boxart. I never got my hands on the first one's box, but I knew about it. And I say this is the boldest (And freaking FUNNIEST) way possible to have an inside joke: put it right on the box!
snippet.textOriginal: To tell the truth, I started madly laughing when I first saw this boxart. I never got my hands on the first one's box, but I knew about it. And I say this is the boldest (And freaking FUNNIEST) way possible to have an inside joke: put it right on the box!

snippet.textDisplay: @CodeLimit Um.... no. Actually, a bit is 1/8 of a byte.
